message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination findings are consistent with plantar fasciitis. Resting of the foot is the initial treatment for plantar fasciitis to allow inflammation to resolve. Orthotic shoe inserts may be helpful for prevention, but they are not the initial treatment. Glucocorticoid injection may also be considered but only after conservative measures have failed. Plain radiograph will not show soft tissue anomalies like plantar fasciitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s description of deep heel pain that worsens with ballet practice suggests plantar fasciitis. Resting the foot is the best next step in management, as it allows time for healing and reduces further strain on the affected area. Orthotic shoe inserts and glucocorticoid injection can also be helpful, but resting the foot should be the first step. Plain radiograph of the foot may be indicated if there is suspected fracture or other pathology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with plantar fasciitis, which is a common overuse injury in athletes that causes inflammation of the plantar fascia. The best next step in management is resting of the foot, which includes discontinuing ballet practice or other high-impact activities that may exacerbate the condition. Orthotic shoe inserts may be helpful in reducing pressure on the plantar fascia, glucocorticoid injections can be considered in refractory cases, and plain radiographs of the foot may be useful in evaluating for other causes of foot pain, but resting the foot is the best initial management strategy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s description of pain and examination findings suggest plantar fasciitis. The best initial management is resting of the foot, advising the patient to avoid exercises and activities that aggravate the pain. If rest alone does not improve the symptoms, orthotic shoe inserts or physical therapy can be considered. Glucocorticoid injection can also be an option but it is usually reserved for cases that do not respond to conservative management. Plain radiograph of the foot is not necessary for the diagnosis and management of plantar fasciitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with plantar fasciitis, which is typically managed with conservative measures such as rest, icing, stretching, and avoidance of exacerbating activities. Orthotic shoe inserts can be helpful for prevention, but may not provide immediate relief. Glucocorticoid injection can be considered if conservative measures fail, but it is not the first line of management. Plain radiograph is not necessary for the diagnosis of plantar fasciitis.

We refer to Mayo Clinic articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest plantar fasciitis, which is commonly seen in ballet dancers. The first-line treatment for plantar fasciitis is rest, so option (D) is the best next step in management. Orthotic shoe inserts may be used to prevent recurrence or provide support, but they are not the first-line treatment. Glucocorticoid injections and radiographs may be used if symptoms persist despite conservative management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest plantar fasciitis, which is common in athletes and dancers. The best next step is to rest the foot, as continued strain on the plantar fascia can worsen the condition. Orthotic shoe inserts can also be helpful in providing support to the foot. Glucocorticoid injection can be considered if conservative measures fail, but radiographic imaging is not necessary unless there is suspicion of a fracture or other underlying pathology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest plantar fasciitis, which is common in ballet dancers due to the repetitive stress on the plantar fascia. Resting the foot is the best initial management for plantar fasciitis. Orthotic shoe inserts may be helpful in preventing recurrence or worsening, but not initially. Glucocorticoid injections and plain radiographs are not necessary for the initial management of plantar fasciitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with plantar fasciitis, which is commonly seen in athletes and individuals who spend a lot of time on their feet. The best initial management option for this condition is rest, so option (D) is correct. Orthotic shoe inserts can also be beneficial in the long term, but rest is needed initially. Glucocorticoid injection and radiographs may be considered later if symptoms persist.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms consistent with plantar fasciitis, which is a common injury in ballet dancers. Resting the foot is often the first-line treatment for plantar fasciitis. While orthotic shoe inserts and glucocorticoid injections can be used in treatment, they are often reserved for more severe cases or if resting does not provide relief. A plain radiograph of the foot may be considered if there are signs of trauma or if suspicion for other conditions such as stress fractures is high.
